title: Putting your children first
introduction:
The needs of your children should come first when you make child arrangements with the other parent.

Your children will feel happier if you can include them in decisions, keep in regular contact and know where to get extra support if they need it.
body_copy:
Your children will be better prepared for a new arrangement if you and the other parent have put their needs first.

Involving your children

Children are more likely to be happier with arrangements if you involve them in decisions. If they understand the situation, make sure to include them whenever possible.

Your arrangements should take into account the changing needs of your children as they grow older. It's important to have a routine but your plans need to be flexible too.

Find out more about involving your children

Contact with your children

Your children will cope better with their situation if they have regular contact with you and the other parent.

Research shows most children still think the parent who has left home is important and part of their family

If you're a non-resident parent and can't find somewhere to see your children you can use a child contact centre. There are around 350 across the UK and Ireland.

There are steps you can take if the other parent is preventing you from seeing your children.

Supporting your children

Your children may need extra support if they're finding it hard to cope.

Counselling

Many schools have professionals children can talk to, but some might need further help from a counsellor.

The type of counselling varies depending on age and if they have any learning difficulties.

Support online

Voices in the Middle is a website that has advice from young people in a similar situation. There's a guide to further help if your children want it.

Where to get emotional support for your children

title: Your parental responsibility
introduction:
Parental responsibility is a legal term that means you have a duty to protect your children and make important decisions for them.

You should know what parental responsibility is, and if you have it, before you start making arrangements.
body_copy:
Parental responsibility is a legal term that means you have a duty to protect your children.

It is not about your rights over them - for example you don't have an automatic right to contact with your children.

If you have parental responsibility your main duties are caring for your children and providing a home for them, even if you don't live together.

You're also responsible for issues such as:

  • where they go to school
  • how to discipline them
  • agreeing to their medical treatment
  • choosing, registering or changing their names

All mothers automatically have parental responsibility. A father usually does if he's either married to the child's mother or listed on the birth certificate.

Find out more about who has parental responsibility.

You can apply for parental responsibility if you don't automatically have it.

You must provide financial support for your children even if you don't have parental responsibility.

Arrange child maintenance yourself

Making decisions with the other parent

You don't always need to get the consent of the other parent when making a decision, even if they also have parental responsibility.

If it's a major decision (for example one of you wants to move abroad with your children) both parents with responsbility must agree.

You can apply for a Prohibited Steps Order from court if you can't agree. A judge will then make a decision which is in your children's best interests.

title: Getting emotional support
introduction:
Emotional support can help you get through the stress of making child arrangements.

You’re more likely to reach an agreement if you’re emotionally ready and know where to get support if you need it.

Contact the Samaritans if you need to speak to someone urgently.
body_copy:
Talking to your friends and family is the most common source of emotional support, but there are other ways you can get help and advice.

Peer support

Using online forums or searching for groups near you is a valuable way of communicating with people who have been through a similar experience.

Use online forums

Online forums allow you to share your story, tell people how you're feeling and discuss any concerns you have.

You can get advice from other by posting a question or sharing your story on a forum.

The following forums are helpful:

  • Parent Connection
  • Dad.info
  • Netmums
  • Wikivorce
  • Gingerbread

Find a group near you

Look for a family meet-up group or single parents network in your local area. Both work in the same way as forums but the focus is usually on meeting face to face.

Professional advice

You should consider professional advice (for example seeing a counsellor or attending a course) if you feel you're struggling to cope.

Counselling

A professional counsellor can help you understand issues such as:

  • how to reduce emotional stress
  • the effect disputes have on your children
  • why your relationship with the other parent ended

The average cost of a counsellor is £35 - £60 per 50-minute session. Fees will depend on your location and the experience of the counsellor.

Some counsellors offer initial sessions for free or reductions if you're unemployed or on a low income.

Relate has a free online chat service that allows you to speak to a trained counsellor in real time. Sessions last around 25 minutes. It also has a telephone service that costs £55 per hour.

Contact the Samaritans if you need to speak to someone urgently.

Find out more about counselling

Find a counsellor near you

Parenting courses

There are courses that can help you and the other parent if you're having difficulties making child arrangements.

The Separated Parents Information Programme teaches you how to put your children first and manage disputes.

The cost of a SPIP is £150 per person, although it's free to attend in some areas.

A judge may order you to attend a SPIP if you take your child arrangments case to court.

Search for a SPIP near you (PDF)

Getting it right for children is a free programme which uses real life situations to show how things can go wrong - and how you can do them better.

Find a parenting course in your area

Emotional readiness

Emotional readiness is being able to put aside your own feelings and any negative thoughts about the other parent.

If you’re emotionally ready you’ll have a better chance of making an agreement that’s in the best interests of your children.

The Children and Family Court Advisory and Support Service (Cafcass) has more information on the steps you need to take to help you become emotionally ready.

title: Use negotiation tools and services
introduction: If you still communicate with the other parent, the cheapest and easiest way to make child arrangements is to negotiate with each other. There are tools and services that can help you.
body_copy:
There are free online tools and services that can help you negotiate an agreement for your children without having to go to court.

You should try and make your arrangements flexible so you can amend them when the needs of your children change.

Parenting plan

A parenting plan is a written or online plan that you use to prepare, discuss and agree child arrangements. It’s not legally binding and you can change the details when your situation changes as your children grow older.

Using a parent plan:

  • helps you know what’s expected of you
  • confirms what you agree (for example, where your children will live)
  • works as a record for you to go back to

You can choose to use an online parenting plan or a plan you can print out.

Negotiating tools

The Negotiations Cycle tool lets you break down your negotiations into 4 stages.

Gingerbread has an arrangements factsheet that includes tips on making negotiating work.

Letter templates

Child Law Advice has a useful letter template if you prefer to negotiate by letter or email.

When negotiating may not be suitable

Child abuse or neglect

You probably shouldn't make arrangements with the other parent if you think they're abusing or neglecting your children.

Report child abuse if you have any concerns and tell your children about Childline so they can report any abuse themselves.

You can report a concern about a child online to the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NSPCC).

Find out more about child abuse and neglect

Domestic violence

Negotiating with the other parent may not be suitable if they pose a threat to your safety.

Report domestic violence if it's safe to do so and you think you're a victim.

You may need to try alternative options if you're worried about the safety of you or your children.
usp_callout: you already agree on the majority of issues but may benefit from using a tool such as a parenting plan.

resources.info:
GOV.UK has information on arranging child maintenance yourself that includes a child maintenance calculator.

Separated Families also has a free online parenting plan

title: Mediation
introduction: Mediation sessions are run by a trained professional who helps you try and reach an agreement without going to court.
body_copy:
You must first meet with a mediator to check if mediation is right for you. This is called a Mediation Information and Assessment Meeting (MIAM).

The mediator will explain:

  • how mediation works
  • the benefits
  • the likely costs
  • if you're eligible for free mediation through legal aid
  • whether it's right for you

Mediation is a voluntary process unless you or the other parent wants to go to court. In this situation you both must show you've considered mediation first.

Attending mediation sessions

Mediation usually takes place over several sessions, each lasting about 90 minutes.

You can choose to have mediation sessions:

  • in the same room
  • in different rooms (shuttle mediation)
  • on different days
  • with your children present (family mediation)
  • with lawyers present (lawyer-assisted mediation)

If you both reach an agreement the mediator will write down all the details.

The agreement isn’t legally binding unless you ask a lawyer to draft a consent order. This can be useful if the arrangements are long and complex.

GOV.UK has more information about consent orders and making your agreement legally binding.

Find a mediator

Lawyer-assisted mediation

This is different to standard mediation because you and the other parent both hire lawyers who attend the sessions with you.

If you have a lot of complex legal issues to resolve this may be a good option because mediators can’t offer legal advice.

When mediation may not be suitable

Child abuse or neglect

You probably shouldn't attend mediation with the other parent if you think they're abusing or neglecting your children.

Report child abuse if you have any concerns and tell your children about Childline so they can report any abuse themselves.

You can report a concern about a child online to the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NSPCC).

Find out more about child abuse and neglect

Domestic violence

Mediation with the other parent may not be suitable if they pose a threat to your safety.

Report domestic violence if it's safe to do so and you think you're a victim.

You may need to try alternative options if you're worried about the safety of you or your children.

Family Mediation Council has more information on the mediation process and how it can benefit you.

The Separated Parents Information Programme is a course that will help you and the other parent understand how to put your children first when separating.

Download a mediation information pack from the Ministry of Justice.

Advice Now has a guide to using mediation following separation.

title: Lawyer negotiation
introduction: You don’t have to deal with the other parent if you choose this option. You each hire a lawyer to negotiate arrangements for you.
body_copy:
You might use lawyer negotiation (also known as solicitor negotiation) if your separation was difficult and you no longer talk to the other parent.

During this process you won’t have to deal with them directly. You’ll both hire a lawyer who will negotiate for you.

Your lawyer will set up an initial meeting with you to discuss the case. You’ll need to explain what the issues are and the outcome you want to achieve.

After receiving instructions from you and the other parent, the lawyers will begin negotiations face-to-face.

As in collaborative law both parties will try and keep the case from going to court.
who_is_involved_caption: Cost will vary dependent on location and the experience of the legal representative. How many hours you need will depend on how complex your situation is.
usp_callout: your relationship is still difficult and you’d prefer not to meet, or there’s a lack of trust.

pros.text: everyone is committed to not going to court
quicker and less stressful than court
you don't have to deal directly with the other parent

cons.text: can be seen as a confrontational approach

title: Collaborative law
introduction: Collaborative lawyers work with you and the other parent to resolve your issues out of court. You each hire a lawyer then all meet to negotiate.
body_copy:
You and the other parent will need to hire a lawyer each. Before the first collaborative meeting (also known as a four-way meeting) your lawyer will want to discuss the case with you.

At the first meeting

Everyone must sign an agreement that commits both parties to resolving the issues out of court.

The agreement also states that if the case does go to court both you and the other parent must hire new lawyers.

This means it’s in everyone’s interests to make sure the negotiations don’t break down.

If you and the other parent reach an agreement the lawyers draw up a document which they submit to court for approval. You won’t have to attend court.

If there's no agreement at the first meeting

You and the other parent must meet with your lawyers to discuss the unresolved issues. A date is then set for a second meeting.
who_is_involved_caption: Costs may vary depending on your location and the experience of your legal representative. How many hours you need will depend on how complex your situation is.
usp_callout: you can still communicate with the other parent but have complex legal issues to resolve.

title: Going to court
introduction: You can go to court if you can't agree on arrangements. A judge will assess your case and make a decision for you
body_copy:
You and the other parent will need to apply for a court order if you can’t agree on child arrangements.

The court process can take a long time and involves several steps.

steps.title: Consider hiring a lawyer
steps.body:
A lawyer will be expensive but they’ll handle the legal aspects of the case and represent you in court.

They may try and negotiate a deal with the other parent out of court or recommend moving to step 2 straight away.

You’ll need to find out how to represent yourself in court if you decide you don’t want to hire a lawyer.

steps.title: Attend a Mediation Information and Assessment Meeting (MIAM)
steps.body:
Before applying for a court order you must attend a MIAM, unless there’s been domestic abuse or social services are involved.

The meeting will assess whether mediation is right you and if you can agree arrangements out of court.

You will need to find a mediator to book a MIAM.

steps.title: Apply for a court order
steps.body:
GOV.UK has more information on how to apply for a court order.

You must give a brief summary of your position and what you want to achieve from the hearing. This is sometimes known as a ‘position statement’.

The court will set a date for a First Hearing Dispute Resolution Appointment (FHDRA). Your date will be about 4 weeks after you apply.

The court will ask an advisor from the Children and Family Court Advisory and Support Service (Cafcass) to provide a report before the FHDRA.

A Cafcass report includes:

  • a social services and criminal record check on you and the other parent
  • details of current arrangements (this may include a record of how the child is feeling)
  • a summary of any other issues the court needs to be aware of

Watch video for more details

steps.title: Go to court
steps.body:
At the FHDRA the court will see if there’s still a chance you can reach an agreement with the other parent. If you can, the judge will write a final order setting out the details.

If there’s no agreement at the first hearing

If you can’t reach an agreement the judge will look at the issues you disagree on and set out a timetable for what will happen next.

GOV.UK has more information on what happens if there’s no agreement at the first hearing.
